title: Woman who lost 7 kg, made 'belly fat disappear' shares 8 things that happen with low sugar intake: Automatic weight loss - Hindustan Times
summary:
Woman who lost 7 kg, made 'belly fat disappear' shares 8 things that happen with low sugar intake: Automatic weight loss

Date: Dec 19, 2024 Source: Hindustan Times

Reducing refined sugar intake can lead to significant changes in health, mood, and physique. Leana documented her personal journey of losing 7 kg, highlighting the changes that come with cutting sugar.

  • Less mood swings
  • Less acne
  • More energy
  • More defined face
  • Less puffy face
  • Automatic weight loss
  • Less bloating
  • Minimized dark circles
“Refined sugar is highly problematic because it’s addictive: the more you consume, the more you crave.”

Leana emphasizes the importance of replacing refined sugars with natural options for effortless weight loss.

title: Deaths from diarrhoeal diseases drop globally: Study - Hindustan Times
summary:
Deaths from Diarrhoeal Diseases Drop Globally: Study

Publication Date: Wednesday, December 19, 2024   Source: Lancet Infectious Diseases

The study published in the Lancet Infectious Diseases indicates a nearly 60% decrease in global deaths from diarrhoeal diseases, while emphasizing that children and the elderly remain the most affected demographics, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia.

  • In 2021, diarrhoeal diseases led to 1.2 million deaths compared to 2.9 million in 1990.
  • Children under five years saw a remarkable 79% decline in mortality rates.
  • Regions with high-income countries reported less than one death per 100,000 children under five.
  • South Asia experienced the highest mortality rates among those aged 70 and older, with 476 deaths per 100,000.
  • Diarrhoeal mortality rates reflected overall declines across age groups globally.
  • The researchers found that disability-adjusted life years (DALYs) shrank from 186 million in 1990 to 59 million in 2021.
"In spite of the encouraging progress made combating diarrhoeal mortality, a multipronged approach is required to simultaneously tackle live-saving solutions while also prioritising preventive interventions to alleviate burdens on health systems." - Dr. Hmwe Hmwe Kyu

The findings underline the need for continued efforts in healthcare interventions to combat diarrheal diseases, particularly focusing on preventive measures and targeted vaccine developments.
newTitle: Deaths from Diarrhoeal Diseases Drop Globally: Study Reveals Improvements and Ongoing Vulnerabilities

title: California declares emergency to combat rising bird flu infection in dairy - The Times of India
summary:
California Declares Emergency to Address Rising Bird Flu in Dairy Sector

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: California Health Department

California has declared an emergency to combat an outbreak of bird flu that is affecting the dairy industry, leading to significant concerns for animal health and economic stability.

  • The emergency declaration allows for expedited resources and actions to address the outbreak.
  • Farmers are being advised on biosecurity measures to contain the spread of the virus.
  • The flu strain has been reported to cause fatalities in infected birds.
  • Poultry and dairy farms in multiple counties are currently under monitoring.
"We are taking immediate steps to protect our livestock and ensure the safety of our food supply," said a spokesperson from the California Health Department.

This emergency response aims to mitigate the effects of the influenza outbreak on both animal populations and the broader agricultural sector.
newTitle: California Declares Emergency to Address Rising Bird Flu in Dairy Sector

How high BP patients found their real triggers: Kidney blockage, sleep apnea among unknown risks - The Indian Express
summary:
How high BP patients found their real triggers: Kidney blockage, sleep apnea among unknown risks

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Indian Express

This article discusses resistant hypertension, detailing two case studies of patients who struggled with high blood pressure despite medication. It highlights the importance of identifying secondary causes to effectively manage and treat the condition.

  • Resistant hypertension affects 20% of patients globally.
  • Case studies revealed underlying conditions like renal artery stenosis and sleep apnea as triggers.
  • Regular monitoring of blood pressure is crucial, especially for those with co-morbidities.
  • Identifying and addressing secondary causes of hypertension can lead to normalization of blood pressure.
“The point is other than known co-morbidities, there are other triggers for BP…”

In conclusion, understanding and identifying the real triggers of resistant hypertension can substantially improve patient outcomes by tailoring effective treatment strategies.
newTitle: Understanding Triggers of Resistant Hypertension: Kidney Issues and Sleep Apnea

title: 12-month diagnosed prevalent cases of severe asthma to reach 1.89 million in 2033 - The Financial Express
summary:
12-month diagnosed prevalent cases of severe asthma to reach 1.89 million in 2033

Date: October 2023 Source: Financial Express

The article discusses the projected increase in diagnosed severe asthma cases due to population growth and low mortality rates associated with the disease. GlobalData forecasts a rise from 1.81 million cases in 2023 to 1.89 million in 2033.

  • The annual growth rate for 12-month diagnosed cases of severe asthma is estimated at 0.49%.
  • Lifetime diagnosed cases are projected to rise from 3.29 million in 2023 to 3.39 million in 2033 at a rate of 0.30% per year.
  • The US is expected to have the highest number of cases, while Japan will have the lowest.
Molly Moran, Senior Epidemiologist at GlobalData, states: "The main reason for the expected increase in the 12-month and lifetime diagnosed prevalent cases of severe asthma is population growth and relatively low mortality associated with asthma."

The article emphasizes the importance of addressing the prevalence and management of severe asthma, particularly in light of increasing population dynamics.
newTitle: Projected Rise in Severe Asthma Cases by 2033

Russia To Launch Cancer Vaccines By 2025 For Free Of Cost: Report - ABP Live
summary:
Russia To Launch Cancer Vaccines By 2025 For Free Of Cost: Report

Published on: Not specified   Source: TASS News Agency

Russia has claimed to have developed its own mRNA vaccine against cancer, which it plans to launch for the general public in early 2025, reported TASS news agency. The vaccine will be distributed free of cost to patients, General Director of the Radiology Medical Research Center of the Russian Ministry of Health Andrey Kaprin has told Radio Rossiya.

  • The vaccine's pre-clinical trials have shown that it suppresses tumor development and potential metastases.
  • Russian President Vladimir Putin mentioned the progress on cancer vaccines that could soon be available to patients.
  • Specific types of cancer targeted by the vaccine have yet to be disclosed.
  • Other countries and firms are also working on cancer vaccine developments, with various collaborations underway.
"We have come very close to the creation of so-called cancer vaccines and immunomodulatory drugs of a new generation," said Vladimir Putin.

This initiative demonstrates Russia's commitment to advancing cancer treatment. However, it remains to be seen how effective the vaccine will be once launched and the specific cancers it aims to address.
newTitle: Russia To Launch Cancer Vaccines By 2025 For Free Of Cost: Report

title: California declares state of emergency amid rising bird flu cases - India Today
summary:
California Declares State of Emergency Amid Rising Bird Flu Cases

Published On: Dec 19, 2024 | Source: India Today

California, the most populous state, has declared an emergency due to the H5N1 virus's spread in dairy herds, following the US's first severe human case of bird flu reported in Louisiana.

  • California declares a state of emergency as H5N1 bird flu spreads among dairy herds.
  • The first severe human case in the US was reported from Louisiana, with the patient in critical condition.
  • Approximately 649 dairy herds in California have tested positive for bird flu since August.
  • CDC confirmed 61 human cases of bird flu nationwide since April, mostly among dairy workers.
  • Health risks are elevated for older individuals with underlying conditions.
  • The emergency declaration allows for expedited response measures in California.
“If you look at the genotype of this patient in Louisiana, it wasn't the cattle strain. It was a wild bird strain.” – Amesh Adalja, Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security

The rising incidence of bird flu in California necessitates urgent public health measures to mitigate the outbreak while ensuring the safety of dairy farm workers and the general population.
newTitle: California Declares State of Emergency Amid Rising Bird Flu Cases

title: Breathing coordinates brain waves for memory storage during sleep - Earth.com
summary:
Breathing Coordinates Brain Waves for Memory Storage During Sleep

Publication Date: [Date Not Provided] | Source: Earth.com

Sleep is essential for restoring the body and mind, a time when memories take root and the brain processes the day’s experiences. Researchers at Northwestern Medicine have uncovered how breathing interacts with brain waves to facilitate memory consolidation during sleep.

Key Points

  • Breathing rhythms are linked to the synchronization of hippocampal brain waves during sleep.
  • This connection is likened to a conductor directing an orchestra.
  • Disordered breathing is associated with poor memory consolidation and increased risk of neurodegenerative conditions.
  • The study highlights the importance of proper breathing for cognitive health.
  • Research indicates that breathing orchestrates the timing of neural oscillations related to memory.
“When you’re sleeping, your brain is actively replaying experiences you had during the day,” said Andrew Sheriff.

The findings emphasize the significance of treatment for disrupted sleep breathing, reinforcing the connection between sleep health and cognitive performance.
newTitle: Breathing Coordinates Brain Waves for Memory Storage During Sleep

title: Sticking to The MIND Diet Could Reduce Your Risk of Developing Dementia - ScienceAlert
summary:
Sticking to The MIND Diet Could Reduce Your Risk of Developing Dementia

Publication Date: Unknown Source: Unknown

The food you eat could either protect you from dementia or put you at higher risk, according to several studies. Two new papers suggest that reducing gut inflammation through diet may help lower dementia risk.

  • A diet high in inflammatory foods increases dementia risk by 84%.
  • The MIND diet, which includes foods that boost antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities, is linked to slower cognitive decline.
  • The research involved over 5,200 older adults, revealing differences in dietary adherence among racial groups.
"Although these promising findings need to be replicated and further validated, our results suggest that diets that correlate with low dietary inflammatory index scores may prevent late-life dementia."

It’s a simple step everyone can take towards lowering their dementia risk.
newTitle: Sticking to The MIND Diet Could Reduce Your Risk of Developing Dementia

summary:
Airborne Microplastics Linked to Lung and Colon Cancers

Publication Date: Unknown | Source: Unknown

This article discusses a recent study which indicates that airborne microplastics can significantly contribute to the development of lung and colon cancers in humans.

  • The study highlights the increasing prevalence of microplastics in the environment.
  • Evidence shows a correlation between microplastic exposure and cancer risk.
  • The research stresses the need for further investigation into the health impacts of microplastics.
“The pervasive presence of microplastics in our air and their potential health effects should be a serious concern for public health.”

title: New Research Shows Eating the Occasional Sweet Treat Is Better for Your Heart Than No Sugar at All - Health.com
summary:
New Research Shows Eating the Occasional Sweet Treat Is Better for Your Heart Than No Sugar at All

Publication Date: December 8, 2023 | Source: Frontiers in Public Health

Eating a small amount of sugar from time to time might be better for your heart than completely eliminating it, according to a new study.

  • The study reports that the impact of added sugar on heart health varies by the type of sugar consumed.
  • Those consuming sugar from pastries and natural toppings like honey had better heart health outcomes than those consuming sugar-sweetened beverages.
  • Moderate sugar intake around 7.5% of daily energy intake is associated with the best cardiovascular outcomes.
  • The average American's sugar intake is significantly higher than the range linked to optimal cardiovascular health.
“The study reinforces that sugar doesn’t have to be eliminated entirely. It’s about moderation, awareness, and balance.” – Kailey Ogilvie, MS, RDN

Overall, while some sugar can be beneficial, it is crucial to consume it in moderation and focus on healthy eating patterns.
newTitle: New Research Shows Eating the Occasional Sweet Treat Is Better for Your Heart Than No Sugar at All

title: Apollo Hospitals performs implantation using TAVI - The Hindu
summary:
India's First Implantation Using New-Generation TAVI System at Apollo Hospitals

Published: December 19, 2024 01:12 am IST

A team of doctors from Apollo Hospitals in Chennai led by G. Sengottuvelu has successfully performed India’s first implantation using the Allegra Transcatheter Aortic Valve Implantation (TAVI) system.

  • The procedure was conducted on a 78-year-old patient who had previously undergone valve replacement surgery.
  • The Allegra valve is a self-expanding TAVI device that overcomes limitations of earlier models.
  • Aortic valve disease is on the rise globally, particularly among the aging population.
  • TAVI is becoming the preferred treatment option for many patients suffering from aortic valve disease.
  • The Allegra valve features a short-frame height design that offers low gradients, better hemodynamic performance, and increased durability.
newTitle: India's First Implantation Using New-Generation TAVI System at Apollo Hospitals

title: Bavarian Nordic Must Prioritize Africa in Localized Mpox Vaccine Production - AIDS Healthcare Foundation
summary:
Bavarian Nordic Must Prioritize Africa in Localized Mpox Vaccine Production

Publication Date: August 2024 Source: AIDS Healthcare Foundation

The AIDS Healthcare Foundation (AHF) calls on Bavarian Nordic to share technology for mpox vaccine production with African manufacturers and to lower vaccine costs for lower-income countries, particularly as the Democratic Republic of the Congo and surrounding areas grapple with significant mpox outbreaks.

  • AHF urges Bavarian Nordic to prioritize Africa in its vaccine distribution strategy.
  • Public Citizen supports the call for equitable access to vaccines through technology sharing.
  • Children are particularly vulnerable, with significant case and fatality rates reported in the DRC.
  • The need for affordable mpox vaccines is critical given historical inequities with COVID-19 vaccine distribution.
“With Africa still bearing the brunt of the mpox outbreak, Bavarian Nordic must prioritize Africa with lower costs, technology transfer, and regional manufacturing...” - Daniel Reijer, AHF Europe Bureau Chief

The call for action emphasizes the importance of equitable vaccine access to prevent further crisis in Africa amidst the ongoing mpox outbreak.
newTitle: Bavarian Nordic Urged to Focus on Africa for Mpox Vaccine Production

title: AHF: Bavarian Nordic Must Prioritize Africa in Localized Mpox Vaccine Production - Business Wire
summary:
AHF: Bavarian Nordic Must Prioritize Africa in Localized Mpox Vaccine Production

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Business Wire

AIDS Healthcare Foundation (AHF) calls on Bavarian Nordic to share vaccine technology with African manufacturers and reduce the cost of the Jynneos vaccine to combat mpox effectively.

“While a recent agreement to share vaccine technology with India is a step forward, it falls woefully short of addressing the urgent need for affordable mpox vaccines where they’re needed most”
  • AHF emphasizes the importance of equitable access to mpox vaccines in Africa.
  • Recent reports indicate over 50,000 confirmed or suspected cases of mpox in the DRC, with severe effects on children.
  • The organization criticizes high-profit motives of pharma companies contributing to vaccine inequity.

AHF aims to prevent repeating the inequities experienced during the COVID-19 pandemic and stresses the need for urgent action.
newTitle: AHF Urges Bavarian Nordic to Focus on Mpox Vaccine Production in Africa

title: CDC Confirms First US Case of Severe Bird Flu - WIRED
summary:
CDC Confirms First Severe Bird Flu Case in the US

Publication Date: December 18, 2024

Source: Wired

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has confirmed the first severe case of avian influenza caused by the H5N1 virus in the United States, marking a concerning shift in the pattern of human infections.

  • The patient, hospitalized in Louisiana, had exposure to sick birds in backyard flocks.
  • This case is the first severe illness linked to H5N1 in the US, previously seen only in mild cases.
  • Since April, 61 human cases of bird flu were reported in the US, all mild until now.
  • The H5N1 virus has significant historical associations with severe illness and high mortality rates in other countries.
  • No person-to-person transmission of H5N1 has been detected, and the public health risk remains low.
“While an investigation into the source of this infection in Louisiana is ongoing, it is believed that the patient that was reported by Louisiana had exposure to sick or dead birds on their property.” – Demetre Daskalakis, CDC

Although this case raises concerns, the CDC reassures that the immediate risk to public health is still regarded as low, urging caution for individuals in contact with infected animals.
newTitle: CDC Confirms First Severe Bird Flu Case in the US

title: US Reports First Severe Infection Of Bird Flu In A Human - NDTV
summary:
First Severe Human Infection of Bird Flu Reported in the US

Publication Date: Wednesday

Source: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)

A patient in Louisiana has been hospitalized with a severe infection of avian influenza, marking the first serious human case in the United States during the current 2024 outbreak, according to the CDC.

  • The total number of avian influenza infections in the US has reached 61 during this outbreak.
  • The patient had exposure to sick and dead birds in backyard flocks.
  • The H5N1 virus belonged to the D1.1 genotype, recently detected in US wild birds and poultry.
  • No evidence suggests human-to-human transmission of the virus.
  • CDC estimates the risk to the general public as low despite these cases.
This case underscores that, in addition to affected commercial poultry and dairy operations, wild birds and backyard flocks also can be a source of exposure.

Concerns are growing about the virus's adaptability and its potential for cross-species transmission, especially given that the outbreak was first reported in March.
newTitle: First Severe Human Infection of Bird Flu Reported in the US

title: Weight loss drugs could help end obesity but risks remain, says WHO - Deccan Herald
summary:
Weight loss drugs could help end obesity but risks remain, says WHO

Published: 18 December 2024, Source: WHO

A new class of weight loss drugs from Novo Nordisk and Eli Lilly may transform the fight against obesity, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). However, the WHO warns of potential risks if health systems fail to plan adequately for their implementation.

  • The WHO claims the new GLP-1 receptor agonists could significantly impact obesity treatment.
  • Concerns exist that reliance on medications alone could diminish attention to comprehensive health strategies.
  • Over a billion people are obese globally, with 5 million obesity-related deaths reported in 2019.
  • The WHO advocates for viewing obesity as a chronic disease necessitating multi-faceted treatment approaches.
  • The agency is developing guidelines for equitable drug distribution and considering their inclusion in its essential medicines list in 2025.
“Medication in isolation will not be enough to address the obesity crisis.” - WHO Chief Scientist Jeremy Farrar

This opinion piece emphasizes the need for a holistic approach that combines lifestyle interventions with new medications to effectively combat obesity worldwide.
newTitle: Weight Loss Drugs Could Help Combat Obesity, Says WHO

title: Scientists know our bodies are full of microplastics. What are they doing to us? - KOSU
3 Ways Parents Protect Kids From Social Media’s Mental Health Effects - Forbes
summary:
3 Ways Parents Protect Kids From Social Media’s Mental Health Effects

Publication Date: December 10, 2024 Source: Forbes

Parents are increasingly aware that too much time on social media can harm kids’ and teens’ mental health. According to research, there are three key ways that parents protect teens from social media’s mental health effects.

Key Points

  • Engagement with their child about social media is crucial.
  • A high-quality relationship with their parents contributes positively to teens' mental health.
  • A high level of parental supervision is essential for better mental health outcomes.
  • Setting limits on social media usage can significantly reduce mental health issues.
  • Most teens report poor mental health correlating with high social media engagement.

Notable Quotes

The surgeon general’s advisory reported in 2023 that almost 95% of youth ages 13 to 17 report using social media, while more than 1 in 3 say they use it “almost constantly.”

In conclusion, engaging with teens about social media, nurturing quality relationships, providing supervision, and setting limits are vital strategies parents can use to protect their kids from the negative mental health effects associated with social media usage.
newTitle: 3 Ways Parents Protect Kids From Social Media’s Mental Health Effects

title: 8 benefits of eating 2 dried apricots every morning - The Times of India
summary:
8 Benefits of Eating 2 Dried Apricots Every Morning

Publication Date: Dec 18, 2024 | Source: Times of India

This article highlights the health advantages of incorporating two dried apricots into your morning routine, detailing eight specific benefits.

  • Dried apricots promote digestive health by containing natural fiber.

  • Dried apricots can enhance energy levels due to natural sugars and minerals.
  • They strengthen bones with calcium and magnesium.
  • They serve as a remedy for iron deficiency, supporting red blood cell production.
“Adding small, healthy habits to daily routine can have a big impact on overall well-being.” - Aadya Jha

Incorporating two dried apricots each morning provides numerous health benefits, supporting digestion, heart health, and overall wellness.

title: United States reports first severe case of bird flu in human, says CDC - WION
summary:
First Severe Bird Flu Case in Humans in the US Reported by CDC

Date: December 18, 2023 | Source: CDC

The CDC has confirmed the first severe case of bird flu in a human in the United States. A patient in Louisiana was hospitalized after being exposed to sick and dead birds.

  • The case was confirmed on December 13, 2023.
  • The patient was exposed to backyard flocks of birds.
  • There have been 61 reported cases in the current outbreak affecting birds and poultry in the US.
  • No human-to-human transmission has been reported.
  • The CDC maintains that the risk to the general public is low.
"...in addition to affected commercial poultry and dairy operations, wild birds and backyard flocks also can be a source of exposure." - CDC

Despite this being the first severe case reported in the US, the CDC reassures that the overall risk remains low for the general public.
newTitle: First Severe Bird Flu Case in Humans in the US Reported by CDC
